price_objections.objection: Your price is [X]% higher than the other bidders
price_objections.wrong_response: We're worth it because we're the best
price_objections.authentic_response: Let's compare the scope matrices side-by-side. Often price differences come from inclusions - are base plates included? Who's providing embed plates? What about touch-up paint after erection? I'd rather make sure you're comparing the same scope, because change orders during erection are where projects really get expensive. Also, can I ask - what's your confidence level that the lower bidder can actually deliver on schedule? Because if they miss your critical path dates, what does that cost the overall project?
price_objections.reframe: Help them see total project cost impact, not just steel package price

timeline_objections.objection: We need steel erected in [X] weeks and you're saying it takes longer
timeline_objections.wrong_response: That's just how long it takes
timeline_objections.authentic_response: I understand the schedule pressure you're under. Let me be straight with you - we can commit to [realistic timeline] if we start detailing this week. What I won't do is promise [unrealistic timeline] and then let you down when it matters most. I've seen contractors promise impossible schedules, then miss them, and the GC ends up paying liquidated damages. Here's what we can do: if you can get us foundation dims verified by [date], we can release anchor rods early and gain back [X] weeks. We can also look at phased delivery - get your first erection area steel while the rest is fabricating. Would that work with your sequence?
timeline_objections.reframe: Position honesty as protecting their interests, offer creative solutions within realistic constraints

relationship_objections.objection: We've worked with [competitor] before and are comfortable with them
relationship_objections.authentic_response: I respect loyalty - it means you value relationships, which tells me you're the kind of client we want to work with. Can I ask what's working well with them? [Listen] That makes sense. The only reason I'd suggest considering us is if you're looking for [specific capability they've mentioned needing]. We've specifically invested in [relevant capability] because we saw projects like yours needing it. But if your current relationship is solid and they're meeting your needs, I'd rather earn your business on the next project where we might be a better fit. Would you be open to us touring you through our shop so you know what we can do when that opportunity comes?
relationship_objections.reframe: Respect existing relationship while planting seeds for future, demonstrate confidence without desperation

capability_objections.objection: This project is bigger/more complex than what we see in your portfolio
capability_objections.authentic_response: You're right to scrutinize capability - this is a significant project and you need confidence we can execute. Here's our honest assessment: [specific aspect] is similar to [past project], where we handled [tonnage/complexity]. The [different aspect] would be new scale for us, which is why I'd propose [specific mitigation - engineering review, third-party inspection, etc.]. What I can tell you is our shop is AISC certified for [category], our QC manager has [X] years including projects like [relevant example], and we'd rather tell you upfront where we'd need support than overpromise. Would it help if our project manager and lead detailer met with your structural engineer to walk through our approach?
capability_objections.reframe: Honesty about limitations with concrete mitigation builds more trust than false bravado

trust_objections.objection: How do I know you'll actually deliver on schedule?
trust_objections.wrong_response: Just trust us, we always deliver
trust_objections.authentic_response: That's the right question to ask, especially if you've been burned before. Here's how we back up our commitments: First, we'll put the delivery schedule in the contract with milestone dates. Second, you'll get weekly fabrication progress reports with photos - you can see your steel being built, not just take our word. Third, we'll give you our project manager's cell number and you can call anytime for real answers. And fourth - and this is important - if we hit a problem that threatens the schedule, you'll know about it the same day we know, not two weeks later. We've built our reputation on communication, and I can give you three references from the last six months you can call right now. Would that give you the confidence you need?
trust_objections.reframe: Replace 'trust me' with verifiable systems and transparency

specification_objections.objection: The engineer specified [competitor/approach] in the drawings
specification_objections.authentic_response: Engineers specify what they're comfortable with, and I respect that. What I'd suggest is we reach out to the engineer together and ask if they're open to an approved equal. We'd provide our AISC certification, our approach to meeting the same performance requirements, and any testing data they need. Sometimes specs are prescriptive because the engineer hasn't seen alternatives, not because alternatives won't work. The benefit to you is potentially [cost savings/schedule improvement/other advantage]. But we'd only proceed with the engineer's written approval - I'm not asking you to take on risk by going around them. Does that approach make sense?
specification_objections.reframe: Work with the system, not against it; position as collaborative problem-solving

Last month, I reviewed a project where the GC "saved" $47K by switching from W14x90 to W14x82 columns.

The result? $180K in change orders.

Here's what value engineering in structural steel actually requires:

You can't just substitute lighter sections. Every connection, every beam-to-column moment, every lateral load transfer must be recalculated. The engineering fees alone for mid-project changes often exceed the material savings.

2. CONNECTION IMPLICATIONS
That lighter column? Now it needs stiffener plates because the web can't handle the beam reactions. You've traded $8/ft in steel for $1,200 per connection in fabrication labor.
